legalRetirementAge.label: Legal Retirement Age
legalRetirementAge.tooltip: Official retirement age when pension benefits begin. In Germany this is typically 67 years old.

endAge.label: Planning Until Age
endAge.tooltip: Age until which to run the simulation. Typically life expectancy (85) plus buffer. Longer planning periods require more conservative withdrawals.

currentAssets.label: Current Assets (€)
currentAssets.tooltip: Total value of your current investments, savings, and retirement accounts. This is your starting point for wealth accumulation.

annualSavings.label: Annual Savings (€)
annualSavings.tooltip: How much you can save and invest each year until retirement. Higher savings rates lead to earlier retirement possibilities.

monthlyPension.label: Monthly Pension (€)
monthlyPension.tooltip: Expected monthly pension from the government system, starting at legal retirement age. This reduces your required private savings.

capitalGainsTax.label: Capital Gains Tax
capitalGainsTax.tooltip: Tax rate on investment gains when selling to cover expenses. German rate: 26.375%. This affects your net withdrawal rates.

averageROI.label: Average ROI
averageROI.tooltip: Expected annual return on investments. Historical stock market: ~7-10%. Bond portfolio: ~3-5%. Diversified portfolio: ~6-8%.

roiVolatility.label: ROI Volatility
roiVolatility.tooltip: Standard deviation of returns. Higher volatility means more uncertainty. Conservative: 5-10%, Moderate: 10-15%, Aggressive: 15-25%.

averageInflation.label: Average Inflation
averageInflation.tooltip: Expected annual inflation rate. ECB target: 2%. Historical average in developed countries: 2-3%.

inflationVolatility.label: Inflation Volatility
inflationVolatility.tooltip: How much inflation varies year-to-year. Historical range: 0.5-1.5%. Higher volatility creates more uncertainty in retirement costs.

simulationRuns.label: Number of Runs
simulationRuns.tooltip: Monte Carlo simulations to run. More runs = higher accuracy but slower computation. 1000+ recommended for reliable results.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.intro: Based on the comprehensive analysis of your financial situation, the following strategic recommendations are provided to optimize your retirement outcomes.

bodies.increaseSavingsRate: Your current success rate indicates potential challenges. Consider increasing your annual savings by 10–20% to improve retirement security.
bodies.delayRetirement: Working an additional 2–3 years could significantly improve your success rate by allowing more time for asset accumulation.
bodies.optimizeInvestmentMix: Review your asset allocation to ensure appropriate balance between growth and stability for your risk tolerance.
bodies.reviewSpendingPlan: Your expenses are high relative to savings. Consider reviewing discretionary spending to improve financial flexibility.
bodies.maximizeTaxDeferred: Ensure you are taking full advantage of tax-advantaged retirement accounts to reduce current tax liability and enhance long-term growth.
bodies.considerVolatilityReduction: Your portfolio has high volatility. As you approach retirement, consider gradually shifting to more stable investments.
bodies.reviewInsuranceCoverage: Evaluate current insurance policies including health, long-term care, and life insurance to ensure adequate protection.

monteCarlo.title: Monte Carlo simulation
monteCarlo.description: This report employs Monte Carlo simulation, a computational technique that uses repeated random sampling to model the probability of different outcomes in retirement planning.

timeSteps.implementation: Annual projections with monthly granularity for expenses

variables.vt: V(t) = Portfolio value at time t

percentiles.title: Percentile calculations
percentiles.description: The report presents three key percentiles from the simulation results:

p10.title: P10 (10th percentile)
p10.detail: Pessimistic scenario – 90% of outcomes exceed this value

p50.title: P50 (50th percentile / median)
p50.detail: Central tendency – half of outcomes above, half below

p90.title: P90 (90th percentile)
p90.detail: Optimistic scenario – only 10% of outcomes exceed this value

success.title: Success rate definition
success.description: A simulation run is considered successful if the portfolio maintains a positive balance through the entire planning horizon (age {age}). The success rate represents the percentage of all simulation runs that meet this criterion.

items.distribution: Returns are assumed to follow a normal distribution, which may not capture extreme market events
items.inflationModel: Inflation is modeled as constant in real terms across all expense categories
items.taxPolicy: Tax rates and regulations are assumed to remain constant
items.unexpected: No consideration for unexpected one-time expenses or windfalls
items.healthcare: Healthcare costs may increase faster than general inflation
items.pension: Pension benefits assumed to be inflation-adjusted and guaranteed

monteCarlo.definition: Statistical technique using random sampling to model uncertainty

successRate.definition: Percentage of simulations where portfolio lasts through planning horizon

sequenceRisk.definition: Risk that poor returns early in retirement significantly impact outcomes
